Native to Central or South Asia, the cannabis plant has been used as a drug for both recreational and [entheogenic](/wiki/Entheogenic_use_of_cannabis) purposes and in various [traditional medicines](/wiki/Traditional_medicine) for centuries. [Tetrahydrocannabinol](/wiki/Tetrahydrocannabinol) (THC) is the main psychoactive component of cannabis, which is one of the 483 known compounds in the plant, including at least 65 other [cannabinoids](/wiki/Cannabinoid), such as [cannabidiol](/wiki/Cannabidiol) [altered states [body movement](/wiki/Motor_skill) (balance and fine psychomotor control), relaxation, and an increase in [appetite](/wiki/Appetite). Onset of effects is felt within minutes when smoked, but may take up to 90 minutes when eaten. The effects last for two to six hours, depending on the amount used. At high doses, mental effects can include [anxiety](/wiki/Anxiety), delusions (including [ideas of reference](/wiki/Ideas_of_reference)), [hallucinations](/wiki/Hallucination), [panic](/wiki/Panic_attack), [paranoia](/wiki/Paranoia), and [psychosis](/wiki/Cannabis_and_psychosis). There is a strong relation between cannabis use and the risk of psychosis, though the direction of [causality](/wiki/Causality) is debated. Physical effects include increased heart rate, difficulty breathing, nausea, and behavioral problems in children whose mothers used cannabis during pregnancy; short-term side effects may also include [dry mouth](/wiki/Xerostomia) and red eyes. [Long-term adverse effects](/wiki/Long-term_effects_of_cannabis) may include addiction, decreased [mental ability](/wiki/Neurocognition) in those who started regular use as adolescents, chronic coughing, susceptibility to [respiratory infections](/wiki/Respiratory_tract_infection), and [cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome](/wiki/Cannabinoid_hyperemesis_syndrome). Cannabis is mostly used recreationally or as a medicinal drug, although it may also be used for spiritual purposes. In 2013, between 128 and 232 million people used cannabis (2.7% to 4.9% of the global population between the ages of 15 and 65). It is the most commonly used largely-illegal drug in the world, with the highest use among adults in [Zambia](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Zambia), the [United States](/wiki/Cannabis_in_the_United_States), [Canada](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Canada), and [Nigeria](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Nigeria). Since the 1970s, the potency of illicit cannabis has increased, with THC levels rising and CBD levels dropping. While cannabis plants have been grown since at least the 3rd millennium BCE, evidence suggests that it was being smoked for psychoactive effects at least 2,500 years ago in the [Pamir Mountains](/wiki/Pamir_Mountains), Asia. Since the 14th century, cannabis has been subject to legal restrictions. The possession, use, and cultivation of cannabis has been [illegal in most countries](/wiki/Legality_of_cannabis) since the 20th century. In 2013, [Uruguay](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Uruguay) became the first country to [legalize](/wiki/Drug_legalization) recreational use of cannabis. Other countries to do so Canada, [Georgia](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Georgia_(country)), [Luxembourg](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Luxembourg), [Malta](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Malta), [Mexico](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Mexico), [South Africa](/wiki/Cannabis_in_South_Africa), and [Thailand](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Thailand). use of cannabis is legalized in [23 states](/wiki/Legality_of_cannabis_by_U.S._jurisdiction), 3 territories, and the [District of Columbia](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Washington,_D.C.), though the drug remains [federally illegal](/wiki/List_of_Schedule_I_drugs_(US)). In [Australia](/wiki/Cannabis_in_Australia), it is legalized only in the [Australian Capital Territory](/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory). Uses Medical Medical cannabis, or medical marijuana, refers to the use of cannabis to treat disease or improve symptoms; however, there is no single agreed-upon definition (e.g., [cannabinoids](/wiki/Cannabinoids) derived from cannabis and synthetic cannabinoids are also used). [[3]](#cite_note-5) [[4]](#cite_note-6) [[5]](#cite_note-Backes2014-7) The rigorous scientific study of cannabis as a medicine has been hampered by production restrictions and by the fact that it is classified as an illegal drug by many governments. [[6]](#cite_note-8) There is some evidence suggesting cannabis can be used to [reduce nausea and vomiting](/wiki/Antiemetic) during [chemotherapy](/wiki/Chemotherapy), to improve appetite in people with [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS), or to treat [chronic pain](/wiki/Chronic_pain) and [muscle spasms](/wiki/Muscle_spasms). Evidence for its use for other medical applications is insufficient for drawing conclusions about safety or efficacy. [[7]](#cite_note-Borgelt2013-9) [[8]](#cite_note-JAMA2015-10) [[9]](#cite_note-11) There is evidence supporting the use of cannabis or its derivatives in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, neuropathic pain, and multiple sclerosis. Lower levels of evidence support its use for AIDS [wasting syndrome](/wiki/Cachexia), epilepsy, rheumatoid arthritis, and glaucoma. [[10]](#cite_note-NEJM2014-12) The medical use of cannabis is legal only in a limited number of territories, including Canada, [[11]](#cite_note-canada2018-13) [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium), Australia, the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands), New Zealand, [[12]](#cite_note-14) [[13]](#cite_note-15) Spain, and [many U.S. states](/wiki/Medical_cannabis_in_the_United_States). This usage generally requires a prescription, and distribution is usually done within a framework defined by local laws. [[45]](#cite_note-:4-47) Adverse effects Short-term Acute negative effects may include anxiety and panic, impaired attention and memory, an increased risk of psychotic symptoms, [[c]](#cite_note-50) the inability to think clearly, and an increased risk of accidents. [[48]](#cite_note-W._Hall,_N._Solowij_1611-16-51) [[49]](#cite_note-52) [[50]](#cite_note-D'Souza-53) Cannabis impairs a person's driving ability, and [THC](/wiki/Tetrahydrocannabinol) was the illicit drug most frequently found in the blood of drivers who have been involved in vehicle crashes. Those with THC in their system are from three to seven times more likely to be the cause of the accident than those who had not used either cannabis or alcohol, although its role is not necessarily causal because THC stays in the bloodstream for days to weeks after intoxication. [[51]](#cite_note-NIH-2-54) [[52]](#cite_note-55) [[d]](#cite_note-58) Some immediate undesired side effects include a decrease in short-term memory, dry mouth, impaired motor skills, reddening of the eyes, [[55]](#cite_note-HallPacula2003ew-59) dizziness, feeling tired and vomiting. [[8]](#cite_note-JAMA2015-10) Some users may experience an episode of acute [psychosis](/wiki/Psychosis), which usually abates after six hours, but in rare instances, heavy users may find the symptoms continuing for many days. [[56]](#cite_note-Barceloux2012-60) Legalization has increased the rates at which children are exposed to cannabis, particularly from edibles. While the toxicity and lethality of THC in children is not known, they are at risk for encephalopathy, hypotension, respiratory depression severe enough to require ventilation, somnolence and coma. [[57]](#cite_note-:13-61) [[58]](#cite_note-62) Fatality Cannabis is suspected of being a potential, and under-reported, contributory factor or direct cause in cases of sudden [death](/wiki/Death), due to the strain it can place on the [cardiovascular system](/wiki/Cardiovascular_system). Multiple deaths have been attributed to [cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome](/wiki/Cannabinoid_hyperemesis_syndrome). [[59]](#cite_note-drummer-63) A 16-month survey of Oregon and Alaska emergency departments found a report of the death of an adult who had been admitted for acute cannabis toxicity. [[60]](#cite_note-64) Long-term Psychological effects A 2015 meta-analysis found that, although a longer period of abstinence was associated with smaller magnitudes of impairment, both retrospective and prospective memory were impaired in cannabis users. The authors concluded that some, but not all, of the deficits associated with cannabis use were reversible. [[62]](#cite_note-66) A 2012 meta-analysis found that deficits in most domains of cognition persisted beyond the acute period of intoxication, but was not evident in studies where subjects were abstinent for more than 25 days. [[63]](#cite_note-Schreiner_2012-67) Few high quality studies have been performed on the long-term effects of cannabis on cognition, and the results were generally inconsistent. [[64]](#cite_note-68) Furthermore, [effect sizes](/wiki/Effect_size) of significant findings were generally small. [[63]](#cite_note-Schreiner_2012-67) One review concluded that, although most cognitive faculties were unimpaired by cannabis use, residual deficits occurred in [executive functions](/wiki/Executive_function). [[65]](#cite_note-69) Impairments in executive functioning are most consistently found in older populations, which may reflect heavier cannabis exposure, or developmental effects associated with adolescent cannabis use. [[66]](#cite_note-70) One review found three prospective cohort studies that examined the relationship between self-reported cannabis use and [intelligence quotient](/wiki/Intelligence_quotient) (IQ). The study following the largest number of heavy cannabis users reported that IQ declined between ages 7-13 and age 38. Poorer school performance and increased incidence of leaving school early were both associated with cannabis use, although a causal relationship was not established. [[67]](#cite_note-Curran2016-71) Cannabis users demonstrated increased activity in task-related brain regions, consistent with reduced processing efficiency. [[68]](#cite_note-72) A reduced [quality of life](/wiki/Quality_of_life) is associated with heavy cannabis use, although the relationship is inconsistent and weaker than for tobacco and other substances. [[69]](#cite_note-Gold2017-73) The direction of [cause and effect](/wiki/Cause_and_effect), however, is unclear. [[69]](#cite_note-Gold2017-73) The [long-term effects of cannabis](/wiki/Long-term_effects_of_cannabis) are not clear. [[8]](#cite_note-JAMA2015-10) There are concerns surrounding [memory and cognition problems](/wiki/Cannabis_and_memory), risk of addiction, and the risk of [schizophrenia](/wiki/Schizophrenia) in young people. [[74]](#cite_note-Weinstein2016-78) [[73]](#cite_note-Batalla2013-77) [[75]](#cite_note-79) Cannabis use is also associated with downregulation of [CB1](/wiki/Cannabinoid_receptor_type_1) receptors. [[67]](#cite_note-Curran2016-71) [[76]](#cite_note-80) [[77]](#cite_note-81) There is limited evidence that chronic cannabis use can reduce levels of [glutamate](/wiki/Glutamate) metabolites in the human brain. [[78]](#cite_note-82) Cannabis dependence About 9% of those who experiment with marijuana eventually become dependent according to [DSM-IV (1994)](/wiki/Diagnostic_and_Statistical_Manual_of_Mental_Disorders) criteria. [[10]](#cite_note-NEJM2014-12) A 2013 review estimates daily use is associated with a 10-20% rate of dependence. [[7]](#cite_note-Borgelt2013-9) The highest risk of cannabis dependence is found in those with a history of poor academic achievement, [deviant behavior](/wiki/Deviance_(sociology)) in childhood and adolescence, rebelliousness, poor parental relationships, or a parental history of drug and alcohol problems. [[79]](#cite_note-83) Of daily users, about 50% experience withdrawal upon cessation of use (i.e. are dependent), characterized by sleep problems, irritability, dysphoria, and craving. [[67]](#cite_note-Curran2016-71) Cannabis withdrawal is less severe than withdrawal from alcohol. [[80]](#cite_note-84) According to [DSM-V](/wiki/DSM-V) criteria, 9% of those who are exposed to cannabis develop cannabis use disorder, compared to 20% for [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_(drug)) and 68% for [nicotine](/wiki/Nicotine). Cannabis use disorder in the DSM-V involves a combination of DSM-IV criteria for cannabis abuse and dependence, plus the addition of craving, without the criterion related to legal troubles. [[290]](#cite_note-295) Cannabis as a gateway drug The gateway hypothesis states that cannabis use increases the probability of trying "harder" drugs. The hypothesis has been hotly debated as it is regarded by some as the primary rationale for the United States prohibition on cannabis use. [[291]](#cite_note-Rand-296) [[292]](#cite_note-Benavie2009x-297) A [Pew Research Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center) poll found that political opposition to marijuana use was significantly associated with concerns about the health effects and whether legalization would increase cannabis use by children. [[293]](#cite_note-298) Some studies state that while there is no proof for the gateway hypothesis, [[294]](#cite_note-MosherAkins2007-299) young cannabis users should still be considered as a risk group for intervention programs. [[295]](#cite_note-journalwatch-300) Other findings indicate that [hard drug](/wiki/Hard_and_soft_drugs) users are likely to be [poly-drug users](/wiki/Poly_drug_use), and that interventions must address the use of multiple drugs instead of a single hard drug. [[296]](#cite_note-301) Almost two-thirds of the poly drug users in the 2009-2010 Scottish Crime and Justice Survey used cannabis. [[297]](#cite_note-302) The gateway effect may appear due to social factors involved in using any illegal drug. Because of the illegal status of cannabis, its consumers are likely to find themselves in situations allowing them to acquaint with individuals using or selling other illegal drugs. [[298]](#cite_note-morral2002-303) [[299]](#cite_note-304) Studies have shown that alcohol and tobacco may additionally be regarded as gateway drugs; [[300]](#cite_note-pmid8246462-305) however, a more parsimonious explanation could be that cannabis is simply more readily available (and at an earlier age) than illegal hard drugs. In turn, alcohol and tobacco are typically easier to obtain at an earlier age than is cannabis (though the reverse may be true in some areas), thus leading to the "gateway sequence" in those individuals, since they are most likely to experiment with any drug offered. [[291]](#cite_note-Rand-296) A related alternative to the gateway hypothesis is the common liability to addiction (CLA) theory. It states that some individuals are, for various reasons, willing to try multiple recreational substances. The "gateway" drugs are merely those that are (usually) available at an earlier age than the harder drugs. Researchers have noted in an extensive review that it is dangerous to present the sequence of events described in gateway "theory" in causative terms as this hinders both research and intervention. [[301]](#cite_note-Vanyukov2012-306) In 2020, the [National Institute on Drug Abuse](/wiki/National_Institute_on_Drug_Abuse) released a study backing allegations that marijuana is a gateway to harder drugs, though not for the majority of marijuana users. [[302]](#cite_note-marijuanagateway-307) The National Institute on Drug Abuse determined that marijuana use is "likely to precede use of other licit and illicit substances" and that "adults who reported marijuana use during the first wave of the survey were more likely than adults who did not use marijuana to develop an alcohol use disorder within 3 years; people who used marijuana and already had an alcohol use disorder at the outset were at greater risk of their alcohol use disorder worsening. Marijuana use is also linked to other substance use disorders including nicotine addiction." [[302]](#cite_note-marijuanagateway-307) It also reported that "These findings are consistent with the idea of marijuana as a "gateway drug." Alcohol and nicotine also prime the brain for a heightened response to other drugs and are, like marijuana, also typically used before a person progresses to other, more harmful substances."
